Nagar, Manauli PO, Mohali, Punjab 140306, India ⁎ Corresponding author. The catalytic double dehydrogenation (DDH) of primary amines is a clean and efficient method over aerobic oxidation. Further, the utilization of bimetallic catalytic system for DDH has proven to be more efficient than its monometallic counterpart. However, its large scale adoption for industrial application is limited owing to the usage of expensive and environmentally adverse catalytic conditions. In this context, the present study describes the first example of tetrazole-derived two bimetallic Ru(II)-arene complexes [(η6-p-cymene)2Ru2Cl3(L1)] [Ru-1] and [(η6-benzene)2Ru2Cl3(L1)] [Ru-2] (where, L1 = 4-(1H-tetrazole-5yl)benzoic acid) for acceptor-less double dehydrogenation of primary amines under oxidant and base free conditions. The results suggest that the electron rich [Ru-1] has outperformed due to its high solubility, high electron density and more charge separation as compared to [Ru-2]. The mechanistic studies reveal that electrophilic centre of [Ru-1] easily associates with substrate, whereas nucleophilic metal centre abstracts β-hydrogen of primary amine via thermodynamically more favourable six-membered transition state as compared to traditional four membered transition state in monometallic system. Further, the catalytic investigation proves that electron rich aromatic primary amines and aliphatic amines are more powerful than bidentate substrates which deactivate the catalyst suggesting the bimetallic dehydrogenation pathway for primary amines. Overall, this research opens the possibility of exploring tetrazole linked bimetallic complexes as an industry efficient solution for transition of primary amines to nitriles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ru(II)-arene complex Bimetallic catalyst Acceptor-less double dehydrogenation Milder condition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitriles and imines are crucial compounds, serving as invaluable foundation for synthesizing a wide array of functional groups such as carboxylic acids, amides, amines, and diverse heterocyclic compounds. These compounds play a pivotal role in the production of essential drugs, pesticides, dyes and much more. Their versatility finds applications across various industries making them indispensable in the field of chemistry [1–5]. Nitriles were traditionally crafted using varied techniques such as dehydration of amide and oxime, via Sandmeyer synthesis, metal-catalyzed cyanation, oxidation of primary amines with iodine or metal-based catalysts and others [6–13]. Among them, the transition metal promoted oxidation of primary amines stands out as a promising avenue for nitrile and imine synthesis, offering two distinct mechanistic pathways i) aerobic oxidation, and ii) double dehydrogenative oxidation as illustrated in Fig. 1 [14]. Aerobic oxidation of amines requires external oxygen source, which produces water as a byproduct [15–18]. This leads to undesirable side reactions, such as hydrolysis of nitriles to amides [18] and hydrolysis of imines to aldehydes and amines [16], which consequently reduce the overall yield. Alternatively, double dehydrogenation (DDH) of primary amines emerges as a promising method, yielding H2 gas as a sole by-product ensuring a clean and efficient conversion. This concept was first introduced by Yoshida and co-workers, illustrating only one example with the help of Rh based catalyst [19]. Following initial breakthrough, pioneering studies on DDH of primary amines were meticulously conducted by Brookhart and his co-workers, they employed Ir-based catalyst with hydrogen acceptor [20], whereas Jensen's group explored this chemistry by adding base with the same Ir based catalyst without hydrogen acceptor [21]. On the other hand, adoption of Ru-based systems has been found remarkably useful for the dehydrogenation of alcohols [22–24]. However, high nucleophilicity and self-coupling nature of primary amines make them undesirable substrates for DDH. Due to that, until 2013 no reports were found to demonstrate DDH of primary amine to nitrile by Ru based catalysts. In 2013, pioneering work was unveiled by Szymczak and co-workers using Ru-NNN pincer based catalytic system [25]. Subsequently, Bera and co-workers made a significant contribution by implementing an efficient pyrazole-based Ru system, wherein crucial role of β-protic center was deduced [26]. In the pursuit of DDH, direct precursor complexes like [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2 have also shown favorable results [27]. To improve precursor-based systems, Muthaiah and his teammates utilized HMTA (hexamethylenetetramine) and their derivatives as base as well as hydride source, and paired them with precursors like RuCl3.nH2O and [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2 [28,29]. Despite positive advancements, the systems discussed above suffer with one or more disadvantages including use of base and hydride source (oxidant), limited substrate scope, and harsh conditions. In 2020, the first efficient bimetallic catalytic system for DDH was introduced by Nie et. al. wherein, N-heterocyclic carbene-nitrogen-phosphine based ligand system was successfully demonstrated [30]. Bimetallic catalytic systems frequently boost the reactivity as compared to their monometallic counterpart due to cooperative action of both metal centers [31–34]. Many bimetallic complexes have demonstrated a diverse range of chemical transformations such as asymmetric synthesis [31] alkyne polymerization and cyclopropanation [35], olefin hydroformylation [36–40], acetoxylation [41], and many more [42–45]. The synthesis of bimetallic system often suffers from tedious and economically unfavorable ligand preparation [30,31]. Also, traditional ligand based catalytic systems sometimes result in low activities, catalyst decomposition, and poor solubility [31]. To avoid that, linker like tetrazoles possess various advantages over traditional ligand systems because of their high chemical stability, low toxicity, easy handling and preparation [46,47]. Though, tetrazole based ligand system has not been used for DDH, its adoption in various oxidation transformations like oxidative coupling [48], oxidative dehydrogenation of benzyl alcohols [49], oxidation of sulfide and alcohol [50], CO2 hydrogenation [51–53], and reduction of aldehydes [54], along with coupling reactions such as Suzuki-Miyaura [55,56], Heck [57], and CN cross-coupling [58] have shown fruitful results. In view of above limitations, it is pertinent to design easy to prepare but strong ligand system which forms stable bimetallic catalysts and support oxidative dehydrogenation under environmental friendly conditions. The adoption of tetrazole based system is found to be particularly beneficial for the preparation of bimetallic complexes. However, despite the perceived benefits the usage of tetrazole based Ru(II)-arene systems for catalytic applications has not been reported so far [59,60]. The present study thus reports the first example of tetrazole based bimetallic Ru(II)-arene complexes for DDH of primary amines to afford nitriles under base and oxidant free benign conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods All the glassware was flame-dried prior to use. RuCl3.xH2O, 4-cynobenzoic acid, cyclohexadiene, and α-phellandrene were procured from Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals and used without further purification. Different benzyl amines were procured from Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals, TCI Chemicals, Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd., Combi Blocks Inc. and Alfa Aesar. AR-grade solvents from Merck were utilized for all the purposes and dried over 4 Å molecular sieves wherever required. Dimeric precursors of Ru(II), [(η6-p-cymene)RuCl2]2 and [(η6-benzene)RuCl2]2 were synthesized and fully characterized using established protocols [61,62]. PerkinElmer spectrum RX 1 was used to collect FT-IR spectra in the range of 400–4000 cm-1 using KBr pellets. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Ascend 400 spectrometers at ambient environment and chemical shifts (δ) in ppm were referenced with internal reference standard (TMS) or the residual hydrogen signal of deuterated solvents. NMR multiplicities are reported as; s for singlet, d for doublet, t for triplet, hept for heptet, sept for septet and m for multiplet signals. MicroOTF-Q II mass spectrometer with +ve scan or -ve scan was used to collect ESI-MS spectrum. Thermoquest EA1110 CHNS/O analyzer was used to collect elemental information. Rigaku XtaLAB mini II Diffractometer was used to gather Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction (SC-XRD) data. The Agilent 5977B EI/CI MSD was used to perform GC–MS experiments. 2.2 Synthesis of L1 4-(1H-tetrazole-5yl)benzoic acid (L1) was synthesized by reported procedure with slight modification [47]. In a flame dried 50 mL RBF 4-cyno benzoic acid (1.470 g, 10 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL dry DMF followed by addition of NaN3 (0.970 g, 15 mmol), and NH4Cl (0.800 g, 15 mmol). The reaction mixture was refluxed for 24 h. The resultant mixture was then dumped into ice cold water. The obtained residues were filtered and washed several times with ice-cold water followed by ether. The crude product was recrystallized in methanol for further use. Yield: 80 %; m.p.: 250 °C; FT-IR (cm-1): 3503[υ(OH)str], 3352[υ(NH)str], 3096 [υ(CH)str], 1707[υ(CO)], 1585[υ(Tetrazole ring)str], 1441[υ(OH)ben], 1328[υ(CN)str], 1303[υ(NNN)str] 1020, 1092, 1117[υ(Tetrazole ring)str]. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, 298 K) δ (ppm): 13.30 [s, 1H, 1 × COOH], 8.14–8.16 [d, 2H, 2 × Ar-H], 8.17–8.19 [d, 2H, 2 × Ar-H], 3.17 [s, 1H, 1 × -NH]. 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 125.78 MHz, 298 K) δ (ppm): 198.23 [CO of COOH], 167.07 [C of tetrazole], 127.61–133.40 [Ar-C]. Mass (−ve scan): m/z 189.3 (Figures S1-S4). 2.3 Synthesis of [Ru-1] A 15 mL solution of [(η6-p-cymene)RuCl2]2 (0.200 g, 0.32 mM) in CH2Cl2 was added dropwise into 10 mL solution of L1 (0.062 g, 0.32 mM) in methanol. The resultant red colored solution was stirred for 24 h at room temperature giving red solid as product. Yield: 83 %; FT-IR (cm-1): 3422[υ(OH)], 2870–3132[υ(CH)], 2959[υ(CH)], 1717[υ(CO)], 1213[υ(CO)]; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz, 298 K) δ (ppm): 8.14–8.16 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C8H5N4O2], 8.05–8.07 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C8H5N4O2], 5.62–5.65 [dd, 4H, 4 × CH of η6-p-cymene], 5.43–5.47 [dd, 4H, 4 × CH of η6-p-cymene], 3.00–3.08 [sept, 2H, CH(CH3)2 of η6-p-cymene], 2.17 [s, 6H, CH3 of η6-p-cymene], 1.27–1.30 [dd, 12H, CH(CH 3)2 of η6-p-cymene]; 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125.78 MHz, 298 K) δ (ppm): 169.53 [C of C8H5N4O2]; 153.38 [CO of C8H5N4O2] 126.21–133.36 [CH of C8H5N4O2], 82.65–82.48 [CH of η6-p-cymene], 30.56 [ CH(CH3)2 of η6-p-cymene], 22.45 [CH(CH3)2 of η6-p-cymene], 18.62 [CH3 of η6-p-cymene]; ESI-MS (+ve scan): [Ru2(η6-p-cymene)2(L1)Cl2]+: 730.94 (m/z); Anal. Calcd. for C28H33Cl3N4O2Ru2 (%): C: 43.90; H:4.34; N:7.31; Obtained: C:43.86; H:4.30; N:7.26 (Figures S5-S8). 2.4 Synthesis of [Ru-2] A precursor complex [(η6-benzene)RuCl2]2 (0.200 g, 0.40 mM) was suspended into 50 mL methanol followed by stirring for 10 min. at room temperature. After that, 15 mL methanolic solution of L1 (0.078 g, 0.40 mM) was added which gave clear red solution after few minutes, continued stirring for 24 h gave red solid as product, which was filtered, and washed with diethyl ether and hexane. Yield: 80 %; FT-IR (cm-1): 3422[υ(OH)], 3062–3075[υ(CH)], 1717[υ(CO)]; 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, 298 K) δ (ppm): 13.18 [s, 1H, 1 × COOH], 8.27–8.29 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C8H5N4O2], 8.12–8.14 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C8H5N4O2], 5.87 [s, 12H, 12 × CH of η6-benzene]; 13C NMR (125.78 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) δ (ppm): 126.27–130.43 [Ar-C of C8H5N4O2]; 88.11–90.76 [Ar-C of η6-benzene]; ESI-MS (+ve scan): [(η6-benzene)2Ru2(L1)Cl2]+= 618.88 (m/z); Anal. Calcd. for C20H17Cl3N4O2Ru2 (%): C:36.74; H:2.62; N:8.57; Obtained: C:36.70; H:2.68, N:8.59 (Figures S9-S12). 2.5 Crystallization, single-crystal data collection, structure refinement and solution The suitable single crystal of [Ru-1] complex was grown via vapour diffusion of diethyl ether into the reaction mixture at room temperature. SC-XRD data set for this compound was collected at 298 K using Rigaku XtaLABmini diffractometer equipped with mercury 375R CCD detector with graphite monochromatic Mo-kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using omega scans. Data reduction was carried out using CrysAlisPro [63], the multi-scan absorption correction method was applied, and space group determination was done using Olex2. The crystal structure of [Ru-1] complex was solved by using SHELXT [64] and refinement was done by using XL [65] available within the Olex2 [66] suite software package. All the hydrogens were fixed geometrically and refined using riding model. 2.6 General procedure for double dehydrogenation (DDH) In a 25 mL flame dried two necked flask, N2 gas was filled, then 0.5 mmol primary amine and 2 mol% [Ru-1]/[Ru-2] was added, followed by addition of 3 mL dry toluene. The reaction mixture was heated at 80 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. After 24 h, reaction mixture was cooled and diluted upto 25 mL by using ethyl acetate, then passed through a short column of silica. The filtrate was subjected to GC–MS analysis. Some representative GC–MS data are shown in Figures S13-S17 and yield calculations are shown in Tables S1 and S2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of ligand and their complexes 4-(1H-tetrazole-5yl) benzoic acid (L1) was synthesized using reported procedure [47] (Scheme 1 ). In FT-IR spectrum of L1, the absence of peak at ∼2250 cm-1 suggests complete conversion of nitrile into tetrazole, whereas peaks at 1020, 1092, and 1117 cm-1 appear due to breathing vibrations of tetrazole ring along with the peak at 1303 cm-1 confirming NNN stretching. The peak at 1585 cm-1 is attributed to the stretching vibrations of tetrazole ring [67]. Also, NMR and mass analyses correlate with the reported work [68]. To get bimetallic [Ru-1], the precursor [(η6-p-cymene)RuCl2]2 in CH2Cl2 was treated with methanolic solution of L1 at room temperature for 24 h (Scheme 2 ). Subsequent slow evaporation gave [Ru-1] with an excellent yield of 83 %. In the 1H NMR spectrum of [Ru-1], protons of L1 appear slightly shielded (8.07–8.18 ppm) as compared to free L1 (8.14–8.19 ppm), which clearly confirm the binding of ligand with Ru(II). All the protons of η6-p-cymene ring systems are de-shielded as compared to precursor dimer showing slight shift of electron density from p-cymene to bonded L1. In 13C NMR spectrum of [Ru-1], all side-chain carbons of η6-p-cymene ring are obtained in the range of 18.65–30.64 ppm, whereas aromatic carbons are in the range of 80.55–104.20 ppm. In the mass spectrum of [Ru-1], isotopic distribution for [Ru2(η6-p-cymene)2(L1)Cl2]+ species is observed as expected at m/z 733.94. Further, elemental analysis confirms the purity of [Ru-1] complex. Analogous bimetallic [Ru-2] was synthesized from precursor [(η6-benzene)RuCl2]2 and L1 in methanol (Scheme 2), resulting in red solid with 80 % yield after 24 h stirring at room temperature. In 1H NMR spectrum of [Ru-2], aromatic signals of L1 are de-shielded (8.12–8.29 ppm) as compared to free L1 (8.14–8.19 ppm), whereas protons of η6-benzene ring are slightly shielded (5.87 ppm) as compared to precursor dimer (5.98 ppm) confirming the binding of L1 and electron density shift from L1 to η6-benzene ring. The presence of peak at 13.2 ppm indicates free COOH proton supporting the binding of L1 through tetrazole ring. In 13C NMR spectrum, carbons of η6-benzene ring resonate at 88.11 ppm, whereas carbons of L1 are obtained at 90.76–130.43 ppm. The mass spectrum of [Ru-2] shows an isotopic distribution pattern at m/z 618.88, which corresponds to simulated pattern for [Ru2(η6-benzene)2(L1)Cl2]+. Further, purity of [Ru-2] has been confirmed by elemental analysis and the results align with the expected formula. 3.2 Structural description and SC-XRD data analysis of [Ru-1] The compound [Ru-1] crystalizes in triclinic P 1 ¯ space group. The molecular arrangement in [Ru-1] displays that two Ru(II) centres are bridged with L1 and one chloride ligand. Each Ru(II) is connected with one nitrogen of tetrazolate anion and bridging chloride ion forming five membered chelate system (Fig. 2 ). The other co-ordinates for Ru(II) centres are engaged by one terminal Cl and one p-cymene ring which form pseudo-octahedral geometries around both Ru(II) centres. Both Ru(II) atoms are situated at the similar distance 2.188 and 2.183 Å from the centre of planer p-cymene ring which represents equivalent environment around both Ru(II) centres. The bond lengths [Ru2-N3 = 2.098 Å; Ru1-Cl1 = 2.4333 Å; Ru1-N2 = 2.107 Å] and bond angles [N3-Ru2-Cl1 = 86.04(8)°; N2-Ru1-Cl1 = 85.37(8)°; Ru2-Cl1-Ru1 = 108.83(3)°] correspond well with the reported systems [59,69]. The important crystallographic information for [Ru-1] is summarized in Table 1 and bond lengths and bond angles are tabulated in Tables S3 and S4. 3.3 DDH of benzyl amine The necessity of base and inert atmosphere for acceptor-less DDH of benzyl amine was checked with 2 mol% [Ru-1] or [Ru-2] at 70 °C (entries 1–7, Table 2 ). Under N2 atmosphere, complete conversion was obtained, whereas under air atmosphere, ∼88 % benzyl amine was converted into products. It was assumed that the catalytic system favours oxidative dehydrogenation over aerobic oxidation (entries 1–2 & 5–6, Table 2). The use of strong base like KOtBu gave complete conversion within stipulated time but lacked in selectivity (entries 3–4, Table 2). On the other hand, base-free system gave an excellent conversion of 95.35 % with 73.17 % selectivity for nitrile in presence of [Ru-1] (entry 5, Table 2). The η6-benzene decorated electron deficient [Ru-2] performed poor as compared to electron rich [Ru-1], probably due to low solubility and presence of electron deficient Ru(II) centre in [Ru-2] (entries 4–7, Table 2). Therefore, further catalytic investigation was carried out by using [Ru-1]. To improve the conversion, increase in time gave good results but selectivity towards nitrile was reduced (entries 8–9, Table 2), whereas rise in temperature improved conversion as well as selectivity (entries 10–11, Table 2). 2 mol% catalyst amount was found to be optimum for this conversion. Further reduction in amount reduced the conversion (entries 12–14, Table 2). Polar aprotic solvents like DMF and THF gave good conversion with lack of selectivity, whereas acetonitrile and DMSO underperformed, assuming that their coordinating nature may compete with substrate and intermediates (entries 15–18, Table 2). Protic solvents like water performed well but lacked in selectivity and produced side products i.e. benzaldehyde (13.57 %) and benzamide (1.03 %) (entry 19, Table 2) as shown in GC–MS data (Figure S15), which proves that water as byproduct enhances the side reactions. Non-polar solvents like 1,4 dioxane performed comparable with toluene with little less selectivity (entry 20, Table 2) which clearly indicates that non-polar solvents are favorable for this conversion as reported in literature. In absence of [Ru-1], no conversion was observed (entry 21, Table 2). Hg(0) poisoning test is important to understand the nature of the catalysis [70–72]. With 600 equiv. of Hg(0), slight decrease in conversion was found which shows catalytic cycle predominately proceeds with homogeneous pathway (entry 22, Table 2). 3.4 Substrate scope for DDH of primary amines With the optimized conditions, scope of benzyl amines was tested. In case of ortho/para monosubstituted benzyl amines, electron donating groups preferentially gave imine as major product (entries 2–4, Table 3 ). The high nucleophilicity of these amines due to electron donating groups may cause imination reaction giving imine as major product. Interestingly, in di-substituted benzyl amine with electron donating groups (OCH3; entry 5, Table 3) gave selectively nitriles as major product as shown in GC–MS data (Figure S16). This may be because of the two electron donating groups which may enhance the reactivity of amine for dehydrogenation (hydride elimination) after binding with Ru(II) of the catalyst. The mono-substituted halide derivatives preferred formation of nitrile derivatives (entries 6–8, Table 3) which can be attributed to reduced nucleophilicity of amines (due to electronegativity of halides) minimizing imination reaction. The two CF3 groups in the amine substrate (entry 9, Table 3) reduce the basicity of amine because of strong -I effect which in turn reduce the binding of amine with Ru(II), resulting in slow reaction and less conversion which reduce the selectivity for nitrile product. The aliphatic amine (entry 10, Table 3) has strong nucleophilic nature which may be helpful in binding with Ru(II) giving high conversion (Figure S17). The poor stability of corresponding imine product due to long alkyl chain may be the reason for no selectivity of imine product giving back the amine substrate undergoing only dehydrogenation or nitrile formation. The catalytic system miserably failed to achieve any conversion for amines which contain two nitrogen atoms (entries 11–17, Table 3) acting as bidentate ligands which may bind strongly with both Ru(II) centres hindering the dehydrogenation step. The adjacent Ru(II) site should be free to perform dehydrogenation or hydride removal process. The results indeed confirm that the dehydrogenation pathway is bimetallic, and tetrazole must have hold both Ru(II) centres strongly. Hydrochloride salts of benzyl amines are readily available because of their stability, so it is important that catalytic system must be useful for hydrochloride salts as well. Two hydrochloride salts were used in presence of equivalent KOtBu as base to neutralize HCl derivatives of benzyl amines. It is important that catalytic system must dehydrogenate benzyl amines without affecting nitro group. The previously reported bimetallic system dehydrogenates the benzyl amines but also reduces nitro group [13]. In present system, nitro derivatives could cleanly produce nitriles without affecting nitro group (entry 18, Table 3). The poor reactivity of nitro derivative can be ascribed to its poor binding ability with Ru(II) as well as less reactivity towards dehydrogenation reaction. The 2-phenylethan-1-amine gave predominately imine derivatives with low conversion (entry 19, Table 3). The hydride removal from non-benzylic position in this amine may be the reason for slow reaction. The study shows that the presence of electron donating groups in aromatic amines favours the formation of nitrile product. In addition, the catalyst is also active for the conversion of aliphatic amine substrate into nitrile, and the amine substrates having two nitrogen atoms deactivate the catalyst towards the reaction. 3.5 Mechanistic investigation The GC-TCD analysis of evolved gas (Figures S18-S20) confirms the formation of H2 gas which proves that the reaction follows double dehydrogenation pathway, also the amount of evolved gas was quantitatively measured which correlates with GC–MS data (Figure S21). [Ru-1] was failed to convert bidentate primary amine substrates (entries 11–17, Table 3), may be because of the difficulty in releasing the ligated bidentate substrate, which leads to catalyst deactivation. Based on that, it is assumed that dehydrogenation process must follow bimetallic dehydrogenation pathway. Further, DFT calculations were carried out with B3LYP/SDD, IEF-PCM(Toluene) for both [Ru-1] and [Ru-2]. In both catalysts, HOMO-LUMO are situated on separate Ru(II) centres with similar energy gap (Figs. 3 & 4 ). Due to that, electronic imbalance is created between both Ru(II) centres, which leads to presence of both electrophilic and nucleophilic Ru(II) centers in same catalytic species. Further, Mulliken charges on both catalysts confirm that [Ru-1] has slightly more negative charges as well as more charge separation between two Ru(II) centers due to alkyl chains which results into more solubility and higher catalytic activity (Fig. 5 ). Benzyl amine exhibits a signal at 3.76 ppm for benzylic protons (Fig. 6 b). The 1H NMR of the reaction mixture in DMSO-d6 after heating at 80 °C for 1 h, was recorded (Fig. 6b). The spectrum exhibits the benzylic -C-H of free benzylamine (δ = 3.77 ppm) as well as of complex bound benzylamine as species C. The signals at 4.37 ppm and 3.47 ppm represent benzylic protons of bound benzylamine; the peak at 4.37 ppm is due to CH proton attached to carbon indicating deshielded proton and the peak at 3.47 ppm is for CH proton which is interacting with metal site showing shielding effect (as Hδ-). The NMR result clearly shows the formation of species C during the reaction. The reaction mixture after 24 h was analyzed by 1H NMR in DMSO-d6 solvent to further confirm the proposed mechanism. The 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. 6c) of reaction mixture after 24 h shows the absence of free benzyl amine in the reaction mixture as there is no signal at 3.77 ppm. This confirms that some amount of benzylamine is converted into the products (nitrile and imine). No signals at 3.47 ppm and 4.37 ppm in the spectrum suggest that species C are converted into other intermediates and products. The signal at 4.65 ppm represents species for CH proton of bound imine interacting with metal site. The CH proton of imine byproduct exhibits signal at 4.77 ppm (Fig. 6c) so the CH proton of metal bound imine will be comparatively more shielded (as Hδ-) and therefore can show upfield shifted signal at 4.65 ppm. The benzylic CH of species C and G will be highly shielded due to their interaction with Ru(II) making them electron rich. The 1H NMR study confirms the interaction of benzylic protons with Ru(II) leading to DDH reaction to produce nitrile product and imine as byproduct. On the basis of mechanistic investigation and computational calculations, the proposed catalytic cycle for [Ru-1] catalyzed DDH as shown in Scheme 3 , initially, the association of benzyl amine with [Ru-1] gives amido species B. The basic nature of tetrazole group may play crucial role during the removal of H + from -NH2 group during the binding of amine substrate with Ru(II). Subsequently, another Ru(II) centre of [Ru-1] abstracts β-hydrogen from the benzyl amine via six-membered transition state (TS) C. Thermodynamically, this six-membered TS is preferred as compared to typical four-membered TS in the monometallic Ru system during β-hydride elimination. Aldimine complex D further forms another six-membered TS E which eventually releases H2 from the substrate and gives imido complex F. Further, imido complex follows similar pathway (C-D) and gives nitrile bounded complex G. Upon addition of new benzyl amine, H2 and nitrile leave the catalyst site, and form catalytically active species C. As shown in Scheme 4 , aldimine intermediate D is susceptible towards nucleophilic attack from benzyl amine which gives benzylidene benzylamine as product and intermediate H. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, two half-sandwich Ru(II) bimetallic complexes [(η6-p-cymene)2Ru2Cl3(L1)] [Ru-1] and [(η6-benzene)2Ru2Cl3(L1)] [Ru-2] (where, L1 = 4-(1H-tetrazole-5yl)benzoic acid) were developed and thoroughly characterized, being the first example for catalytic application. Both the complexes were used for acceptor-less double dehydrogenation of primary amine to nitrile and imine under base and oxidant free environment using milder conditions. The electronically rich catalytic system [Ru-1] showcased excellent activity and stability as compared to electronically poor [Ru-2]. DFT study confirmed the presence of electronic imbalance within the catalysts, leading to catalyst activation. In situ 1H NMR study confirmed the proposed mechanism for DDH via thermodynamically more favourable six-membered transition state. The product selectivity was purely found to be dependent on steric control. The substrate scope investigation revealed that bimetallic system remains intact during the catalysis but failed to release ligated bidentate ligand, which leads to deactivation of the catalyst. The present work will pave the way for the advancement of easy to prepare and highly stable tetrazole linked Ru(II) bimetallic complexes for enduring homogeneous dehydrogenative processes and also potential catalyst for the dehydrogenation of Liquid Organic Hydrogen Carries (LOHCs). coredata.dc:description: The catalytic double dehydrogenation (DDH) of primary amines is a clean and efficient method over aerobic oxidation. Further, the utilization of bimetallic catalytic system for DDH has proven to be more efficient than its monometallic counterpart. However, its large scale adoption for industrial application is limited owing to the usage of expensive and environmentally adverse catalytic conditions. In this context, the present study describes the first example of tetrazole-derived two bimetallic Ru(II)-arene complexes [(η6-p-cymene)2Ru2Cl3(L1)] [Ru-1] and [(η6-benzene)2Ru2Cl3(L1)] [Ru-2] (where, L1 = 4-(1H-tetrazole-5yl)benzoic acid) for acceptor-less double dehydrogenation of primary amines under oxidant and base free conditions. The results suggest that the electron rich [Ru-1] has outperformed due to its high solubility, high electron density and more charge separation as compared to [Ru-2]. The mechanistic studies reveal that electrophilic centre of [Ru-1] easily associates with substrate, whereas nucleophilic metal centre abstracts β-hydrogen of primary amine via thermodynamically more favourable six-membered transition state as compared to traditional four membered transition state in monometallic system. Further, the catalytic investigation proves that electron rich aromatic primary amines and aliphatic amines are more powerful than bidentate substrates which deactivate the catalyst suggesting the bimetallic dehydrogenation pathway for primary amines. Overall, this research opens the possibility of exploring tetrazole linked bimetallic complexes as an industry efficient solution for transition of primary amines to nitriles.
